awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Automated Proof Construction and Verification for Attribute-based Cryptography
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a comprehensive proof construction and verification framework for a well-defined class of cryptographic protocols: attribute-based cryptosystems. In particular, existing automated proof construction and verification frameworks, such as EasyCrypt and CryptoVerif, are extended to provide support for attribute-based cryptography. The extensions consist of libraries of simple transformations, algebraic manipulations, commonly used abstractions and constructs, and proof strategies, which will help in generation and verification of proofs in attribute-based cryptography. Additionally, the investigator seeks to understand the limitations, if any, on the development of verification tools for attribute-based cryptosystems.

The project builds upon and expands the scope of the toolset to include other classes of cryptographic protocols, such as identity-based cryptosystems, and non-interactive zero-knowledge proofs, which share the same underlying mathematical assumptions and constructs. All code and modules produced from this peoject will be compatible with existing proof verification tools. Educational activities are an integral part of this project. This project provides undergraduate and master's-level students an introduction to, and an opportunity to work on an advanced area in cryptography, and provide an opportunity to work with state-of-the-art model-checkers, and proof assistants.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

 The goal of this project was to develop automated tools for generation and verification of proofs of attribute-based cryptosystems. To this end, we developed tools for automation of building blocks such as pairing-based signature schemes, and short group signature schemes. We used these tools to automate the proofs of two well-regarded attribute-based signature schemes. This project also provided us the opportunity to explore the application of attribute-based cryptosystems to various domains such as blockchains, cryptocurrencies and payment channel networks.

 

We explored the application of attribute-based encryption and our proof techniques to diverse domains such as pervasive edge computing, public auditability mechanisms, designing blockchain rewriting mechanisms, payment channel networks and more.

 

Broader impacts:

In terms of broader impacts, the project supported several students: two Ph.D. students and two M.S. students at New Mexico State University. The project has supported diversity in computing by supporting women graduate students. The Ph.D. and M.S. students have several first-author publications to their credit. All students received valuable research experience, and learned critical thinking skills, technical writing and communication skills (while writing and publishing their research results), besides getting valuable coding and software development experience. The project also helped the PI establish a new research lab at New Mexico State University.

 

The results of the project have been disseminated in various academic peer-reviewed conferences such as ACM Conference on Computer and Communication Security (ACM CCS), ACM Conference on Data and Application Security (ACM CODASPY), IEEE International Conference on Blockchain and Cryptocurrency (IEEE ICBC), ACM Symposium on Access Control Models and Technologies (ACM SACMAT), International Conference on Availability, Reliability and Security (ARES), International Conference on Privacy, Security and Trust (PST) among others.
